results.title: A Curriculum based on child development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Elementary School Teacher Education”.
Projects undertaken by typical fourth-grade students are used in explaining the methods employed by an elementary school teacher to adapt the curriculum to the needs of her pupils. Points out that the developmental characteristics of pre-adolescents must be considered in all phases of the curriculum.

results.title: Each child is different
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Elementary School Teacher Education”.
Dramatised incidents are used in presenting a study of five fifth-grade children, whose personalities and backgrounds present typical problems. The film explains the importance of the elementary school teacher’s knowledge of the complex and different backgrounds of the children, as well as their individual abilities and needs, in order to adjust the teaching program to meet these needs.

results.title: Making learning more meaningful
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Elementary School Teacher Education”.
Learning arithmetic and money-handling by producing play money - setting up a mint, a bank and a grocery store in a primary school grade.

results.title: Developmental characteristics of pre-adolescence
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and Herbert Kerkow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Elementary School Teacher Education”.
As the child grows toward maturity, successive stages of development are apparent - each stage has a distinctive pattern of behaviour. A study of the daily life of an eight-year-old girl and a nine-year-old boy illustrates the chief development characteristics of pre-adolescents. Their patterns of behaviour provide information on developing a curriculum suitable to their needs and educational experiences.

results.title: Electricity Safety
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

group_works.title: New cords for old, and the golden rule
group_works.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Lex Halliday and Instructional Films for S E C

results.title: New cords for old, and the golden rule
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films, Lex Halliday and Instructional Films for S E C
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Electricity Safety”.
Do not keep old damaged electrical cords, and never try to repair them. Common causes of accidents are frayed cords, and badly repaired cords, broken plugs, and two cord flexes used instead of three cord flexes. Once insulation becomes worn or damaged wires are exposed which may cause shocks. Hows correct way of wiring new plugs and recommends that it is a job for an expert.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Instructional Films, Lex Halliday and Instructional Films for S E C

group_works.title: Joining solid conductors
group_works.creator_credit: Visual Aids, US Office of Education

results.title: Joining solid conductors
results.creator_credit: Visual Aids, US Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Electrical Wiring”.
How to make the following joints: “Western Union”, pigtail, plain tap, wrapped tap (or Britannica), loop tap and fixture joints; how to use a blow-torch; how to flux and solder joints, and insulate them.

results.title: Repulsion motor principles
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of Education and Ray-Bell Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Electrical work: electrical machinery”.
Explains construction of repulsion motor, rotor circuits and effects of brush position; short-circuiting and brush-lifting mechanism; and application of repulsion motors. This film is a technical training film on the design and construction of repulsion brush type electric A.C. motors as used in the first half of this century.
